questions: Q. 1. Where do you find green glands?
answers: Ans. In prawns (crustaceans).

questions: Q. 2. Name two parts of a nephron.
answers: Ans. (a) Glomerulus (b) Renal tubule.

questions: Q. 3. From where the pelvis receives urine?
answers: Ans. The pelvis receives urine from collecting tubules via calyces.

questions: Q. 4. Which is the most toxic product formed in animals?
answers: Ans. Ammonia (NH2) is the most toxic product formed in animals.

questions: Q. 5. Give the total amount of water excreted daily through human body.
answers: Ans. The total amount of water excreted daily through human body is 2.60 litres.

questions: Q. 6. Name the organs concerned with excretion in man.
answers: Ans. Kidneys are the major excretory organs. Other accessory excretory structures are liver, lungs, skin and intestine.

questions: Q. 7. Why ammonia is converted to uric acid crystals directly in uricotelic organisms?
answers: Ans. Animals which live in dry conditions have to conserve water in their bodies. Therefore, they synthesize crystals of uric acid from their ammonia.

questions: Q. 8. Where are the kidneys located in human beings?
answers: Ans. The kidneys are located between the levels of the last thoracic and third lumbar vertebrae close to the dorsal inner wall of the abdominal cavity.

questions: Q. 9. What are the ducts of Bellini?
answers: Ans. These are the collecting ducts which unite together in the medulla to form the longer duct, the duct of Bellini.

questions: Q. 10. Name two high threshold substances.
answers: Ans. Glucose and amino acids are two threshold substances.

questions: Q. 11. What is a Malpighian corpuscle?
answers: Ans. Bowman's capsule and glomerulus are collectively known as Malpighian corpuscles.

questions: Q. 12. What are osmoconformers?
answers: Ans. Osmoconformers are those animals which show changes in the body fluid concentration according to the concentration of surrounding medium.

questions: Q. 13. What are guanotelic animals?
answers: Ans. The three process of urine formation are: (a) Ultrafiltration, (b) Selective reabsorption (c) Tubular secretion.

questions: Q. 15. Why is sweat considered as a excretory waste?
answers: Ans. Sweat is considered as a excretory waste because it contains nitrogenous wastes, dissolved salts and excess of water.

questions: Q. 16. Expand the following terms: (i) ANF (ii) JGA
answers: Ans. (i) ANF: Atrial Natriuretic Factor (ii) JGA: Juxta Glomerular Apparatus.

questions: Q. 17. What are renal calculi?
answers: Ans. Stone or insoluble mass of crystallised salts such as oxalates are called as renal calculi.

questions: Q. 18. What happens in glomerulonephritis?
answers: Ans. Inflammation of glomeruli of the kidneys.

questions: Q. 19. What is gout?
answers: Ans. High level of uric acid accumulation in the body which tends to solidify into crystals and are deposited in the joints and kidneys.

questions: Q. 20. What is osmoregulation?
answers: Ans. Removal of excess water from the body to keep water content constant is called osmoregulation.

questions: Q. 21. How thyroxine deficiency affects the urine?
answers: Ans. Thyroxine deficiency decreases the urine output.

questions: Q. 22. Define osmolarity.
answers: Ans. Osmolarity is the total solute concentration of two solutions.

questions: Q. 23. Name the enzyme produced by kidney to convert angiotensinogen to angiotensin.
answers: Ans. Renin converts angiotensinogen to angiotensin.

questions: Q. 24. What is urinolysis?
answers: Ans. An analysis of urine is called urinolysis which provides information about the physical, chemical and microscopic properties of urine.

questions: Q. 25. What is the function of juxta-medullary nephrons?
answers: Ans. Juxta-medullary nephrons control plasma volume when water supply is short.

questions: Q. 26. What is the role of anti-diuretic hormone in excretion?
answers: Ans. Anti-diuretic hormone increases the reabsorption of water in the distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct.

questions: Q. 27. How is uremia caused? Define the term uremia.
answers: Ans. Uremia is caused by high concentration of urea in the blood.

questions: Q. 28. Expand RAAS.
answers: Ans. RAAS is Renin Angiotensinogen Aldosterone system.

questions: Q. 29. If urine contains blood what does this indicates?
answers: Ans. If urine contains blood, this indicates there has been some injury or damage to the filters of the kidneys.

questions: Q. 30. What is diuretic? Give Examples.
answers: Ans. A substance which increase the volume of urine excreted is called diuretic. e.g., tea, coffee etc.
